contents: The first two years of these two programs are near-identical. Then, in the third year of the SE degree, students spend a whole year (roughly 40 working weeks) in an industry placement. They work in a software firm engaging in all facets of software development process, from design to deployment. Final year (third in CS and fourth in SE) are slightly different, in that, SE students will do another large in-house project and more SE electives, while CS students will do a slightly smaller project and a few more core courses and electives.

In the initial two years, the Software Engineering and Computer Science programs closely mirror each other. During the third year, Software Engineering students undertake a year-long industry placement, immersing in all stages of software development. The concluding year varies slightly, with Software Engineering students taking on a large in-house project and further electives, and Computer Science students pursuing more core courses and electives.

The first two years of both Software Engineering and Computer Science share similar course structures. Software Engineering students then spend a full year in the industry, encompassing all software development phases. The final year diverges, with Software Engineering focusing on a major in-house project and additional electives, and Computer Science accentuating core courses and electives.

The Software Engineering and Computer Science programs align closely for the first two years. However, the third year sees Software Engineering students in a year-long industry immersion, participating in the complete software development process. The concluding year has a distinct focus, with Software Engineering tackling a substantial in-house project and more electives, and Computer Science delving into additional core courses and electives.

The initial two years in both Software Engineering and Computer Science are quite similar. From there, Software Engineering students dedicate a year to industry experience, engaging fully in software development. The final year shows a slight difference, as Software Engineering students embark on a larger in-house project and further electives, while Computer Science students handle more core courses and electives.

Software Engineering and Computer Science programs are nearly identical for the first two years. The third year sees Software Engineering students undertaking a year-long industry placement, interacting with every aspect of software development. The final year sees some differentiation, with Software Engineering students completing a large-scale in-house project and additional electives, while Computer Science students focus on more core and elective courses.

Depending on the program, a wide choice of electives -- in programming, mobile, and web, networking, cybersecurity, software engineering, is available. In addition, In general, each program has a suite of electives you can choose from. However, if you are interested in taking an elective outside the program structure, you can seek approval from the program manager. In the IT program, you can choose your electives to form a specialisation in one of the IT sub-disciplines (programming, security, DEVOPS, etc) or you can choose them broadly.
"Programs offer various electives like programming, cybersecurity, and more. You can specialise by choosing related electives, or choose broadly. Electives outside of the program require approval."
Each program provides a wide array of electives, enabling specialisation or broad learning. Electives outside the given structure need program manager's approval.
Electives in IT subjects allow specialisation or general learning. Permission is required for electives outside the set program.
"Various electives facilitate specialisation in IT sub-disciplines or broad learning. Approval is needed for electives beyond the program structure."
Programs offer diverse electives for specialisation or wider learning. Electives outside the standard program need manager approval."

Unfortunately we do not have such a formal double degree. However, there are a number of cross-disciplinary majors and minors available and some of them have a strong business focus. BIT students have the widest choice of majors and minors.

While we don't offer a structured double degree, students can choose from numerous cross-disciplinary majors and minors, some with a strong business focus. BIT students have the widest range of options."
There isn't a specific double degree, but we do have a selection of cross-disciplinary majors and minors, with a few emphasising business. BIT students have the greatest choice.
We may not provide a formal double degree, but many business-centric cross-disciplinary majors and minors are available. BIT students have the most diverse options.
Although there's no designated double degree, we present a variety of cross-disciplinary majors and minors, some with a business orientation. BIT students have the most extensive selection.

We don't have a designated double degree, but we offer a multitude of cross-disciplinary majors and minors, some with a significant business component. BIT students have the broadest range to choose from.
WE have one double degree: 1. CS with Computer and Network Engineering. They are 5-year degrees with ⅖ CS and ⅗ engineering.

We offer a single double degree program, namely Computer Science paired with Computer and Network Engineering. This is a 5-year course where two-fifths is dedicated to Computer Science and three-fifths to engineering.

We provide a double degree option in Computer Science and Computer and Network Engineering. This spans over five years, with 40% of the time focused on Computer Science and the remaining 60% on engineering.

Our institution has a double degree program: Computer Science combined with Computer and Network Engineering. It's a 5-year course, with Computer Science comprising two out of five parts, and engineering making up the rest.

We possess a singular double degree, which is Computer Science and Computer and Network Engineering. It's a five-year program, with a 40-60 split between Computer Science and engineering, respectively.

Our educational offerings include one double degree: Computer Science along with Computer and Network Engineering. This five-year program allocates two-fifths of the curriculum to Computer Science and three-fifths to engineering.

No. RMIT’s SE degree is very much software development focussed degree, and it does not teach principles of engineering design. Also, there is no advanced math courses, such as Calculus, engineering maths, and statistics in our SE degree. However, they still be required to one discrete maths subject. However, it meets the international standards in SE industry ACM and IEEE guidelines on SE curriculum, and also accredited by Australian Computer Society.
RMIT's SE degree, focused on software development, doesn't teach engineering design or advanced math, but includes a discrete maths subject. It meets ACM, IEEE, and ACS standards.
RMIT's SE degree, oriented towards software development, lacks engineering design principles or advanced math, but requires one discrete maths course. It's internationally and ACS-accredited.
RMIT's software-centric SE degree excludes engineering design and advanced math, barring one discrete maths subject. It fulfills ACM, IEEE, and ACS guidelines.
RMIT's SE degree, with a software development focus, omits engineering design and advanced math, except for a discrete maths module. It adheres to ACM, IEEE, and ACS standards.
RMIT's SE degree emphasizes software development, not engineering design or advanced math, except for one discrete maths subject. It's compliant with international SE industry and ACS standards.
Yes, except the Data Science degree, all other programs are accredited by ACS at professional level.
Indeed, with the exception of the Data Science degree, all other programs hold professional-level accreditation from ACS.
Yes, barring the Data Science degree, all other programs have been given professional level accreditation by ACS.
Indeed, except for the Data Science degree, ACS has granted professional-level accreditation to all other programs.
Yes, all programs, apart from the Data Science degree, have secured professional-level accreditation from ACS.
Certainly, with the exception of the Data Science degree, ACS has accredited all other programs at the professional level.

Well, not directly. We do have a lot of industry contacts, as well as a full-time industry coordinator who will assist students to establish industry links. In addition, towards the second part of second year, we run a number of professional development activities to assist students to get themselves prepared for applying industry placements. In the worst comes to worst, we will transfer SE students to CS program if -- after every possible avenue is exhausted -- they cannot secure an industry placement.
While not directly, we help students connect with industry contacts and prepare for placements. In worst-case scenarios, we may transfer SE students to the CS program.
We don't provide placements directly but assist students with industry connections and placement preparation. SE students can switch to the CS program if necessary.
We don't place students directly but offer industry contacts and preparation for placements. If unsuccessful, we transfer SE students to the CS program.
Though not directly, we support students with industry networking and readiness for placements. SE students may be moved to the CS program if required.
We don't directly offer placements but facilitate industry connections and preparation. If all fails, SE students could be transferred to the CS program.
Yes, under government regulations, all internships are within Australia are paid internships. However, if you choose an overseas internship, they may come under the host country’s regulations.
Indeed, according to governmental rules, internships within Australia are paid positions. But bear in mind, if you opt for an internship abroad, the pay regulations of the host country will apply.

Certainly, per the Australian government's regulations, all internships in Australia are paid. However, if you select an internship outside Australia, the remuneration may be subject to the rules of that particular country.
Absolutely, as per government rules, internships within Australia should be paid. But if you decide to intern overseas, the pay guidelines of the host country might come into effect.
Yes, by government mandate, all internships in Australia are paid. But if your internship is in a foreign country, that country's pay regulations would apply.
Indeed, all internships in Australia are paid as per government regulations. However, should you opt for an internship abroad, you would be subject to the regulations of the host country.

RMIT degrees are quite specific in the discipline area, for example, our degrees are titled Bachelor of Computer Science, Bachelor of Software Engineering, Bachelor of Information Technology, and Bachelor of Data Science. In addition to the above, we offer an honours degree option: a one-year Honours degree which is only be started after completing a regular three year CS degree. It is called Bachelor of Computer Science (Honours). This is not available for Year 12 entry students. We used to offer a Deans Scholar degree, however, it is not offered in 2023.

RMIT offers discipline-specific degrees such as Computer Science, Software Engineering, Information Technology, and Data Science. A one-year Honours degree in Computer Science is available after a three-year course. The Deans Scholar degree isn't offered in 2023.

RMIT provides distinct degrees like Computer Science, Software Engineering, IT, and Data Science. An additional one-year Honours degree in Computer Science is available post three-year course completion. The Deans Scholar degree isn't available in 2023.

RMIT offers specific degrees such as Computer Science, Software Engineering, IT, and Data Science. Post a three-year course, a one-year Honours degree in Computer Science can be pursued. The Deans Scholar degree isn't offered in 2023.

At RMIT, students can choose from distinct degrees like Computer Science, Software Engineering, IT, and Data Science. A post-three-year-course one-year Honours degree in Computer Science is available. The Deans Scholar degree isn't offered in 2023.

RMIT specializes in degrees like Computer Science, Software Engineering, IT, and Data Science. An additional one-year Honours degree in Computer Science can be taken after a three-year course. The Deans Scholar degree isn't available in 2023.

RMIT provides pathways for students excel in one program to transfer into another program, as long as they meet certain criteria. For example, if you enrol in IT program, maintain above Distinction-level average, AND specifically do a Discrete Structures course in their first year, they may apply to transfer into CS program after completing a full year. This is not a guaranteed path, however, you have the control. If you do extremely well in your first year (even if you do not have VCE Maths Methods), you have a good chance that you transferred into CS program after one year.

RMIT allows high-achieving students to transfer programs given certain conditions. For instance, IT students with high grades and completion of a Discrete Structures course could apply for a CS program. Success is not guaranteed but depends on performance.

RMIT offers the chance for students to switch programs based on specific criteria. Notably, IT students with above Distinction-level grades and a completed Discrete Structures course may apply for a CS transfer. It's not assured but is performance-dependent.

At RMIT, students meeting certain standards can transfer programs. For example, IT students with high averages and a Discrete Structures course might apply for a CS program. It isn't guaranteed but hinges on first-year performance.

RMIT allows transfer between programs for students who excel and meet certain requirements. Specifically, IT students with strong grades and a Discrete Structures course could apply for a CS program. It's not certain, but performance plays a key role.

RMIT offers program transfer opportunities for high-performing students who meet specific criteria. Notably, IT students with strong grades and a Discrete Structures course could apply for a CS program. It's not a guarantee but depends on first-year performance.

No. you won’t get full credit, you will get credit for the common courses between these two programs. We have a pathway study plan for such students. Roughly speaking you can get credit for 75% of the courses you do in first year IT.
You'll receive credit for shared courses between the two programs, not full credit. We provide a pathway plan, with approximately 75% of first-year IT courses credited.
Full credit isn't granted. However, credit for common courses is given. We offer a pathway plan, where around 75% of first-year IT courses can earn credit.
You won't receive full credit, but credit is given for courses common to both programs. We have a pathway plan, enabling credit for nearly 75% of first-year IT courses.
Full credit isn't possible, but common courses can earn credit. We offer a pathway study plan, with about 75% of first-year IT courses credited.
While full credit isn't provided, you'll get credit for shared courses. Our pathway study plan allows roughly 75% of first-year IT courses to be credited.

There is no direct answer. It is easy between some programs, and not as easy between some programs. For example, within first and second year, it is easy to transfer between SE and CS programs. Also, if you go from SE or CS to IT, it is easy to transfer. However, going up, such as IT to CS, will require certain requirements and assessed on merit.

Program transfers depend on the specific programs. Transfers between Software Engineering and Computer Science, or from Software Engineering or Computer Science to Information Technology, are easier during the first two years. However, upward transfers like Information Technology to Computer Science require merit-based assessments.

Transfers between programs vary. It's simpler to switch between Software Engineering and Computer Science or from Software Engineering or Computer Science to Information Technology in the early years. However, transfers from Information Technology to Computer Science require assessments based on merit.

Program transfer ease varies. For instance, switching between Software Engineering and Computer Science or from Software Engineering or Computer Science to Information Technology is easier in the first two years. But, transferring from Information Technology to Computer Science needs certain requirements and is merit-based.

Transfers are easier between some programs, such as Software Engineering and Computer Science or from Software Engineering or Computer Science to Information Technology, especially during the first two years. However, transfers like Information Technology to Computer Science are merit-assessed and require specific criteria.

The ease of program transfers depends. It's easier to transfer between Software Engineering and Computer Science or from Software Engineering or Computer Science to Information Technology in the initial years. Transferring from Information Technology to Computer Science, however, is merit-based and requires certain conditions.

There is a multitude of WIL components available, some are part of the programs and mandatory and others are optional. SE students are required to do one-year industry placement and another 24CP project in their final year. Same for all three professional degrees. All other students are required by RMIT rules to do a capstone project in their final year. It involves with doing a project with an industry partner, or in some cases, an in-house project simulating a real industry scenario. In each case, they are assigned a project supervisor who work closely with you and industry partner to get student experience. In addition to these mandatory WIL requirements, every year we have summer projects and other industry events, such as ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and other coding/ security competitions.

A wide variety of Work-Integrated Learning, or WIL components, are available for you. These can be both mandatory and optional, depending on your program. If you're studying Software Engineering or any of the professional degrees, a year-long industry placement and a final year project are required. All students need to complete a capstone project in their final year, which may be with an industry partner or simulated as a real industry scenario. For these projects, a dedicated supervisor will work closely with you. Additionally, summer projects and industry events, including ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and various coding or security competitions, are also available each year.

There are numerous Work-Integrated Learning options, some of which are mandatory and others that are optional. As a Software Engineering student or enrolled in any of the professional degrees, you're required to take part in a year of industry placement and a 24-credit-point final year project. It's a requirement for all students to undertake a capstone project in their final year, involving a collaboration with an industry partner or an in-house project mimicking real industry situations. A project supervisor will be assigned to work with you closely. We also have summer projects and other industry events such as the ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and various coding or security competitions.

You have a range of Work-Integrated Learning options to choose from, some compulsory and others optional. If you're pursuing Software Engineering or any other professional degree, a year of industry placement and a final year project are mandatory. All students must undertake a capstone project in their final year, where they may work with an industry partner or simulate an industry environment. You will have a project supervisor for guidance. We also offer additional opportunities like summer projects and industry events, such as the ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and various coding and security competitions.

RMIT provides an array of Work-Integrated Learning opportunities. Some are essential parts of the programs while others are optional. If you're a Software Engineering student or in any of the professional degrees, a one-year industry placement and a final-year project are required. All RMIT students must carry out a capstone project in their final year, working with an industry partner or in a simulated industry scenario, with a dedicated project supervisor for assistance. Moreover, RMIT offers summer projects and industry events like the ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and coding or security competitions each year.

There's a multitude of Work-Integrated Learning components available at RMIT. Some are mandatory, while others are optional. As a Software Engineering student or a student of any professional degree, you're required to complete a year of industry placement and a final year project. All RMIT students must complete a capstone project in their final year, working closely with an industry partner or in a simulated industry scenario, guided by a project supervisor. Plus, every year, we offer summer projects and industry events such as the ANZ hackathon, AIIA iAwards competition, and various coding and security competitions.
No, it is not. You are required to apply when you are closer to the completion of the Associate Degree.
No, that's not the case. You need to apply when you are nearing the completion of your Associate Degree.
That's incorrect. The application is required when you are close to finishing your Associate Degree.
No, it's not so. You should submit your application when you're about to complete the Associate Degree.
That's not true. You need to apply when you're nearly done with your Associate Degree.

That’s a myth. Yes, some low-end jobs were outsourced such as call centres, however, there is a growing IT industry, especially, within startups, innovative IT technologies, such as home automation, Internet of things, machine learning, etc, which are not, and will not be, outsourced and Melbourne is always at the forefront of these developments. Also, IT-support jobs, in small to medium scale companies, will still remain locally. There were 91000 job adverts in the first half of 2021 alone. 530,000 (more than half a million, out of a workforce of 16.5 million) work in IT sector. What really matters is that job demand in IT sector is growing, for last 11 years (since 2007-08 downturn) and never looked back since 2007-08. Link: https://joboutlook.gov.au/Occupation.aspx?search=Career&code=2613 You can find the demand for other skills and compare it with ICT professionals and see it for yourself.

It's a misconception that IT jobs are mostly outsourced. In fact, sectors like startups and innovative technologies are booming locally. Melbourne leads in these areas. Over 90,000 IT jobs were advertised in 2021 alone.

Contrary to popular belief, not all IT jobs are outsourced. Advanced fields like home automation and machine learning are expanding locally, with Melbourne at the forefront. The first half of 2021 saw over 90,000 IT job adverts.

The idea that most IT jobs are outsourced is a myth. Emerging sectors like home automation and IoT aren't outsourced and Melbourne is leading in these areas. There were 91,000 job adverts in the IT sector in early 2021.

Dispelling the myth, not all IT jobs are outsourced. Sectors like startups, innovative tech, and IT-support jobs in SMEs stay local, especially in Melbourne. There were 91,000 IT job adverts in the first half of 2021.
It's inaccurate to think most IT jobs are outsourced. Innovation sectors and IT-support roles in smaller companies often remain local. In 2021's first half, there were 91,000 IT job advertisements.
Absolutely. Associate degrees normally have lower ATAR and quite suitable pathway to achieve your intended graduation outcome via this.
Definitely. Associate degrees usually require lower ATAR scores and provide a feasible route to reach your desired graduation goals.
"Indeed. An associate degree typically demands a lower ATAR, making it a suitable pathway to attain your targeted degree."
Without a doubt. Associate degrees, which generally require lower ATAR, can be an effective way to achieve your intended educational outcome.
Certainly. With typically lower ATAR prerequisites, associate degrees can be an ideal route to fulfill your graduation aspirations.
Absolutely. Given their generally lower ATAR requirements, associate degrees could be the perfect path for achieving your desired graduation objectives.

This is a very broad question. Our students have successfully obtained jobs in many IT-related sectors, government, large IT companies, small-to-medium scale companies, startups and so on. Lately, there is a flurry of activity in Melbourne in startups. Many of our students have joined them, and some of them even have started their own startups.
Our students find success in various IT fields, including government, large corporations, small businesses, and startups, with many in Melbourne's thriving startup scene.
From governmental roles to startups, our students secure jobs across the IT spectrum. Some have even launched their own startups, particularly in Melbourne's bustling scene.
Our students excel in multiple IT sectors, from government to startups, including launching their own businesses, especially within Melbourne's vibrant startup environment.
Students from our institution have made their mark across IT sectors including government, IT firms, startups, with a notable presence in Melbourne's burgeoning startup scene.
Spanning government, corporate, and startup sectors, our students have found career success in IT. Some have even spearheaded their own startups in Melbourne's lively entrepreneurial ecosystem.
Yes, careers outlook for games industry, in more broader sense, the digital media is very positive.
Indeed, the future prospects for careers in the gaming industry, and in a larger context, digital media, are very promising.
Certainly, there is a positive career projection for the games industry, and more broadly, for the digital media sector.
Absolutely, the job outlook for the games industry and, more extensively, the digital media field, is quite optimistic.
Yes, the forecast for career opportunities in the games industry and, in a wider sense, digital media, is very encouraging.
Indeed, the career prospects in the games industry, and more comprehensively, the digital media sector, are highly positive.

The Professional version is just introduced, and first intake will be 2023. Students in the regular (3-yr version), if they perform really well in the first two years, they can apply for an internal transfer into the professional version (4-yr version). It is essentially added internship year to the regular program. The full-year internship (40 weeks) is similar to what Software Engineering students do in their third year. However, you may be able to choose a wider range of companies that suits your preferred career path (cyber security, data science, machine learning, etc).

The Professional version, introduced for 2023, allows high-performing regular students to transfer for an added internship year, similar to the Software Engineering program, offering a variety of career path choices.

The new 2023 Professional version gives top-performing regular program students a chance to add an internship year, aligning with the Software Engineering course, while expanding potential career paths.

The Professional version, launching in 2023, is an opportunity for standout students in the regular program to undertake an extra internship year, akin to Software Engineering, but with broader career options.

Debuting in 2023, the Professional version enables high-achieving regular program students to gain an internship year, much like Software Engineering students, but with a wider choice of career paths.

The Professional version, coming in 2023, allows exceptional regular program students to incorporate an internship year, similar to Software Engineering, with diverse career possibilities in fields like cyber security, data science, and machine learning.

CS program covers Computer Science core body of knowledge and will provide a solid foundation in the underlying concepts. It strikes a good balance between the theory and the application of these theories to the application of them into real-life scenarios (in application development). The IT program tip more into the applications with more emphasis on hands-on skills in various aspects of ICT (information and communication technology). Our IT degree has more degree of freedom (much more flexible) in customising the program to your taste, say, if you interested in explore in one aspect of IT (mobile app development, or networking, or security, or business analysis), you can choose your majors and minors in such a way, or if you prefer to go across the breadth.

The Computer Science program provides a firm foundation in core knowledge, effectively blending theory with its practical application. The Information Technology program, more application-centric, emphasizes hands-on skills across various ICT facets. The IT program offers great flexibility for customization based on your specific interests.

The Computer Science program offers a balance of theoretical understanding and real-world application, whereas the Information Technology program leans towards practical applications in various ICT sectors. The IT degree permits significant customization to align with your interests.

While Computer Science offers a blend of theoretical underpinnings and their application, the Information Technology program is heavily skewed towards practical ICT skills. The IT degree provides extensive flexibility to cater to your unique interests and preferences.

The Computer Science program emphasizes a combination of theory and its real-world application, while the Information Technology program focuses on practical ICT skills. With the IT degree, you have the liberty to shape the program to your personal interests.

Our Computer Science program is rooted in theory and its practical use, while Information Technology is more applied and emphasizes hands-on ICT skills. The IT degree provides ample room for customization according to your interests.

Not really. What matters the most is how you performed in your degree. Also, the skills outside the main (such as communication, professional skills, etc) will play an important role in finding a job. A weak CS student with minimal communication skills will find it difficult to find a job than an excellent IT student. No matter what degree you do, do really well and you find jobs.

Bachelor of Software Engineering students learn to design, build and maintain software solutions through industry-led learning and a 1-year internship, honing their skills to meet stakeholder needs. Meanwhile, Bachelor of Engineering in Software Engineering is a degree that combines engineering practices and embedded systems, with a focus on programming for sensors, IoT devices, and digital electronics. It includes a research component, which takes up less time for industry practice.

Bachelor of Software Engineering graduates are more specialized in software design and development, whereas Bachelor of Engineering in Software Engineering graduates have a broader range of skills in engineering and embedded systems.
